content.title: Self-Expanding Stents
content.description: Vascular stents that expand to vessel diameter upon deployment, made from nitinol (nickel-titanium alloy) with shape memory properties.
content.mechanism: Nitinol's shape memory allows stent to be constrained during delivery and expand to predetermined diameter at body temperature.

characteristics.radial_force: Chronic outward force resists external compression

indications: Vessels subject to external compression (SFA, popliteal)
content.deployment_technique: Positioned under fluoroscopy, unsheathed to allow controlled expansion
limitations: Cannot be post-dilated to larger diameter
May not fully expand in calcified lesions
Precise positioning more difficult than balloon-expandable
content.statement: Self-Expanding Stents is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Procedures Stent that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding Self-Expanding Stents helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of Self-Expanding Stents include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Self-Expanding Stents.

citations.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.
